journal-meta.journal-title: The American Journal of Sports Medicine

title-group.article-title: Complications of Medial Patellofemoral Ligament Reconstruction in Young Patients

article-meta.aff: †Division of Orthopaedic Surgery, Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, Ohio
Investigation performed at the Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, Cincinnati, Ohio

author-notes.corresp: *Shital N. Parikh, MD, Division of Orthopaedic Surgery, Cincinnati Children’s Hospital Medical Center, 3333 Burnet Avenue, MLC 2017, Cincinnati, OH 45229 (e-mail: shital.parikh@cchmc.org).

permissions.copyright-holder: American Orthopaedic Society for Sports Medicine

sec.title: Background:
sec.p: The medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) has been recognized as the primary restraint to lateral subluxation of the patella. Reconstruction of the MPFL for patellar instability has demonstrated early clinical success, but postoperative complications have rarely been reported, especially in young patients.

sec.title: Purpose:
sec.p: To assess early complications (<3 years) of MPFL reconstruction in young patients.

sec.title: Study Design:
sec.p: Case series; Level of evidence, 4.

sec.title: Methods:
sec.p: The charts and radiographs of all patients who underwent MPFL reconstruction between 2005 and 2011 were retrospectively reviewed to identify postoperative complications. A complication was considered major if the patient required hospitalization or further surgery. Each complication was analyzed to identify the technical factors related to it.

sec.title: Results:
sec.p: A total of 179 knees underwent MPFL reconstruction during the study period. There were 38 complications in 29 knees (16.2%), with 34 major and 4 minor. Major complications included recurrent lateral patellar instability (8 patients), knee motion stiffness with flexion deficits (8 patients), patellar fractures (6 patients), and patellofemoral arthrosis/pain (5 patients). Eighteen of 38 (47%) complications were secondary to technical factors and were considered preventable. Female sex and bilateral MPFL reconstructions were risk factors associated with postoperative complications.

sec.title: Conclusion:
sec.p: Complications occurred in 16.2% of MPFL reconstruction surgeries for patellar instability in young patients, with almost half resulting from technical problems. Patients should be counseled preoperatively on the risk of potential complications.

body.p: Anatomic and biomechanical studies have shown that the medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) is the primary restraint to lateral translation of the patella.2,7,12,20,41 Several techniques of MPFL reconstruction for patellar instability have been described in the literature with favorable clinical and radiological outcomes.‡ However, this early success of MPFL reconstruction has overshadowed the potential complications of the procedure. The aim of our study was to identify and analyze early complications (<3 years) related to MPFL reconstruction in young patients (<21 years of age). Identifying complications and their potential causes will help to anticipate, treat, and potentially prevent future complications.

A systematic review of MPFL reconstruction studies concluded that most trials were small case series, many had limited follow-up, and a majority employed other adjunctive techniques besides MPFL reconstruction, making it difficult to distinguish the determining factors in their outcomes.5 Tanaka et al37 reviewed the literature and reported on common technical errors and potential complications from MPFL reconstruction, including errors in patient selection, graft tensioning, graft fixation, and tunnel placement. This study is the first report on the incidence of complications after MPFL reconstruction in a large series of patients treated at a single institution.

sec.title: Materials and Methods
sec.p: After obtaining approval from the institutional review board, we searched the hospital surgical database to identify consecutive patients who underwent MPFL reconstruction at our institution from 2005 through 2011. Patients with a history of congenital patellar dislocation (4 patients) and those older than 21 years of age (3 patients) were excluded. Two patients who underwent revision MPFL reconstruction at our institution but had their primary surgery performed at an outside facility were included in the study to analyze the cause of failure. A total of 179 knees in 154 consecutive patients were identified. The mean age of patients was 14.5 ± 2.6 years (range, 6-21 years). There were 91 female and 63 male patients. Twenty-five patients had bilateral MPFL reconstructions, and 129 had unilateral MPFL reconstructions. The average follow-up was 16.2 months, with a median of 12 months (interquartile range, 3.5-26 months). All procedures were performed by 1 of the 2 authors (S.N.P., E.J.W.), using similar surgical principles and rehabilitation protocols. The indications for MPFL reconstruction were recurrent (2 or more episodes) patellar instability after failure of nonoperative treatment or primary patellar instability with an osteochondral fracture that had to be addressed. Preoperative workup included clinical evaluation for generalized hyperlaxity and for coronal, sagittal, and rotational plane alignment. Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) was performed, and tibial tubercle–trochlear groove distance was measured. Patients with bilateral patellar instability and physiological hyperlaxity were referred to the Division of Human Genetics for further evaluation.

The medical records and radiographs of all patients were reviewed for demographic information (age, sex, height, weight, and body mass index [BMI]) and to identify complications related to the surgical procedure. Complications were categorized as major if the patient returned to the operating room or required hospitalization after the index procedure. Complications were categorized as minor complications if they were treated on an outpatient basis. All complications were analyzed to identify the probable cause.

Reconstruction of the MPFL was performed in isolation without concomitant lateral release (except in habitual patellar dislocations) or distal realignment. During MPFL reconstruction, a diagnostic knee arthroscopic procedure was performed, followed by harvest of an ipsilateral hamstring tendon graft, preferably the gracilis. The hamstring autograft was looped through bone tunnels in the patella, and both free ends were passed between layer 2 (medial retinaculum) and layer 3 (capsule) on the medial side of the knee (Figure 1). The isometry of the graft was confirmed by placing the graft or a suture through the patellar tunnel, looping it around the Beath pin at the femoral attachment point and then observing for less than 5 mm of length changes with flexion-extension of the knee.34 The ends of the graft were then placed in the femoral tunnel and fixed with a bioabsorbable interference screw, with the knee in about 45° of flexion. Through the years, modifications have been made to the technique by each author including single patellar tunnel and fluoroscopic verification of the femoral tunnel (see online video supplement). In skeletally immature patients with an open distal femoral physis, either a soft tissue technique of MPFL reconstruction without bony tunnels was used,25 or the femoral tunnel was placed just distal to the distal femoral physis.13,15 Since 2011, we have not performed MPFL repair because a study from our institution by May et al (unpublished data, 2011) comparing MPFL repair and MPFL reconstruction had shown better clinical outcomes with MPFL reconstruction at a minimum 2-year follow-up.

caption.p: Schematic diagram of medial patellofemoral ligament (MPFL) reconstruction using a single medial-sided patellar tunnel and interference screw fixation in the femoral tunnel, with medial (M) and lateral (L) sides indicated. The MPFL graft is placed between layer 2, or the retinacular layer (black arrow), and layer 3, or the capsular layer (dashed arrow).

sec.p: Femoral tunnel placement was analyzed using postoperative radiographs or MRI in patients who had complications. For radiographic measurement (Figure 2), the anatomic attachment point, as described by Schöttle et al,30 was marked at a distance of 1.3 mm anterior to the posterior cortical line and 2.5 mm distal to the line perpendicular to the posterior cortical line and passing through the top of the posterior femoral condyle. A circle with a radius of 5.5 mm (usual size of the femoral tunnel) around the anatomic femoral attachment point was used as a reference to calculate the distance of the femoral tunnel.31 If there were no acceptable postoperative lateral radiographs, then MRI was used to determine the position of the femoral tunnel (Figure 3), as described by Servien et al.31 On the first medial sagittal MRI slice that passes through the femoral tunnel, the distance between the articular surface of the posterior medial femoral condyle and the center of the femoral tunnel was measured, and a distance between 20 and 30 mm was considered normal. A distance greater than 30 mm was considered too anterior. Similarly, on a coronal view, the distance between the articular surface of the medial femoral condyle and center of the femoral tunnel was measured, and a distance between 25 and 35 mm was considered normal. A distance more than 35 mm was considered too proximal.

caption.p: Radiographic measurement of femoral tunnel placement. On a lateral radiograph, the anatomic medial patellofemoral ligament attachment point (A) is marked. A circle with a 5.5-mm radius with the anatomic point as its center marks the acceptable position of the femoral tunnel. The center of the femoral tunnel is marked (B). The distance between the circle and point B is calculated. For this radiograph, the femoral tunnel is 13.5 mm anterior (line 1). In a proximal-distal direction, the femoral tunnel is acceptable as line 2 is less than 5.5 mm.

Magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) measurement of femoral tunnel position. (A) On the first sagittal MRI slice of the medial femoral condyle that goes through the femoral tunnel, line 1 represents the tangent to the posterior articular surface of the condyle. Line 2 is parallel to line 1 and passes through the center of the femoral tunnel. The femoral tunnel should be between 20 and 30 mm from the posterior articular surface. Here, the femoral tunnel is 2.8 mm too anterior. (B) A coronal MRI scan shows the medial patellofemoral ligament graft looped around the medial retinaculum (arrow). A line connecting the articular surfaces of the condyles is marked. The perpendicular distance between this line and the femoral tunnel marks the location of the tunnel in a proximal-distal direction. The femoral tunnel should be between 25 and 35 mm from the articular surface. Here, the femoral tunnel is 16.8 mm too proximal.

sec.title: Statistical Analysis
sec.p: An independent-samples t test was used to determine whether patients with and without complications differed in age, height, weight, or BMI. Fisher exact tests and relative risk ratios were performed to determine whether male or female patients were at a greater risk of complications, whether patients who underwent bilateral or unilateral surgeries had a greater risk of complications, and whether patients 12 years of age and younger or older had a greater risk of complications.

sec.title: Results
sec.p: Of 179 knees, 29 knees in 27 patients (16.2% of knees) had an identifiable complication. The mean age of these 27 patients was 14.9 ± 3 years (range, 7-20 years). There were 24 female and 3 male patients. Of the 29 knees, 12 involved the left side and 13 the right side, and 2 were bilateral. Seven of 27 patients (26%) had bilateral MPFL reconstructions. Two patients had complications related to both knees, and 5 had complications related to 1 knee.

There was a total of 38 complications, of which 34 were considered major and 4 minor (Table 1). One knee had 4 complications (3 major, 1 minor). One knee had 3 complications (3 major). Four knees had 2 complications, and the remaining 23 knees had 1 complication each. The average time between surgery and presentation of the complication was 275 days (range, 4-1095 days) (Table 1).

caption.p: Complications in 27 Patients With Medial Patellofemoral Ligament Reconstructiona

tr.td: Hematoma drained (64), revision-arthrosis (653), femoral screw removed (1053)
Revision-instability, lateral retinacular release, tibial tubercle osteotomy (455)
Deep vein thrombosis (4), complex regional pain syndrome (8),b wound dehiscence (9), MUA (98)
Subsequent tibial tubercle osteotomy for pain (186)

fn.label: a
fn.p: F, female; L, left; M, male; MUA, manipulation under anesthesia; R, right.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Minor complication per definition, treated nonoperatively.

sec.p: Eight patients experienced recurrent lateral patellar instability after MPFL reconstruction; 6 of these 8 patients underwent repeat surgery. Five patients underwent revision MPFL reconstruction, and 1 patient underwent lateral retinacular release. Two patients were treated with physical therapy and bracing. Two patients had their index procedures performed at an outside institution. One of these 2 patients also underwent a revision MPFL reconstruction at an outside institution. One patient underwent a concomitant lateral retinacular release and tibial tubercle osteotomy at the time of revision MPFL reconstruction. One patient underwent manipulation under anesthesia (MUA) 6 weeks after revision MPFL reconstruction. Postoperative evaluation showed femoral tunnel malposition in 7 of the 8 patients (Table 2).

caption.p: Position and Distance of Femoral Tunnel Malposition

fn.label: a
fn.p: Anterior and proximal positioning was seen in patients who had soft tissue medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction.

fn.label: b
fn.p: Same skeletally immature patient, with deliberate anterior and distal positioning of the femoral tunnel.

sec.p: Eight patients demonstrated restricted flexion of the knee during follow-up. No patients had extension deficits. All patients regained full range of motion after MUA and continued with physical therapy. Analysis of imaging of 5 patients showed anterior placement of the femoral tunnel in 3 patients and anterior and distal placement in 2 patients (Table 2).

Six patients had patellar fractures (Table 3). The 5 transverse patellar fractures were through patellar tunnels; 4 of them were treated with tension band wiring (Figure 4A). One patient sustained a nondisplaced transverse patellar fracture after direct trauma to the knee. He was treated with an above-knee cast (Figure 4B). A female patient sustained a superior pole avulsion fracture of the patella when she fell and hyperflexed her knee. Just before her fall, she demonstrated significant restricted range of motion, and her radiographs showed anterior placement of the femoral tunnel. She was treated with quadriceps tendon repair. A year later, she demonstrated persistent extensor lag and quadriceps weakness and was advised to continue physical therapy.

caption.p: Patellar Fractures After Medial Patellofemoral Ligament Reconstruction

tr.td: Transverse fracture through the inferior tunnel
Transverse fracture through the superior tunnel
Superior pole avulsion not involving the tunnel

caption.p: (A) Patellar fracture through the inferior tunnel that was stabilized with tension band wiring. (B) Computed tomography scan of a nondisplaced patellar fracture through both patellar tunnels, treated with immobilization.

sec.p: Five patients with progressive patellofemoral arthrosis/pain did not respond to anti-inflammatory drugs, physical therapy, intra-articular cortisone injections, and limitation of activities. Radiological evaluation in 3 of the 4 patients revealed significant anterior placement of the femoral tunnel during the index procedure (Table 2). Magnetic resonance imaging showed increased chondral lesions in the patella, which was confirmed by arthroscopic surgery during revision MPFL reconstruction (Figure 5). One patient had a soft tissue MPFL reconstruction as an index procedure. Magnetic resonance imaging revealed anterior and proximal attachments of the graft on the femoral side. Four of the 5 patients underwent revision MPFL reconstruction, and 1 patient with habitual patellar dislocations underwent tibial tubercle osteotomy. Anatomic femoral tunnel placement during revision MPFL reconstruction alleviated symptoms in all patients. One patient underwent subsequent debridement with removal of a femoral interference screw.

caption.p: Axial magnetic resonance imaging scan of a patient with increasing patellar pain shows chondral lesions of the patella (filled arrow) and an incompetent medial patellofemoral ligament graft (unfilled arrows). The patella is subluxated laterally.

sec.p: Eighteen of the 38 (47%) complications were considered to be related to improper technique. These included 12 patients with recurrent patellar instability or patellofemoral arthrosis/pain due to improper femoral tunnel placement (Table 2) and 6 patients with patellar fractures. Other complications are listed in Table 1.

Patients with and without complications did not differ in age (14.93 ± 3.10 years vs 14.46 ± 2.54 years, respectively; t test, t = −0.82, P = .41), height (166.36 ± 9.20 cm vs 167.22 ± 13.94 cm, respectively; t test, t = −0.29, P = .77), weight (74.60 ± 28.09 kg vs 73.28 ± 25.75 kg, respectively; t test, t = 0.23, P = .82), or BMI (26.92 ± 9.83 vs 25.74 ± 7.18, respectively; t test, t = 0.69, P = .50). Female patients were found to have a 5.45 times greater risk of complications after MPFL reconstruction surgery than male patients (relative risk [RR], 5.54; 95% confidence interval [CI], 1.74-17.60). This increased risk was statistically significant (Fisher exact test, P < .001), with 26% (24/91) of female patients and 5% (3/63) of male patients having complications. Bilateral MPFL reconstructive surgeries were found to have a 1.81 times greater risk of complications than unilateral MPFL reconstructive surgeries (RR, 1.81; 95% CI, 0.86-3.81). This increased risk was not statistically significant (Fisher exact test, P = .11), with 28% (7/25) of bilateral surgeries and 15% (20/129) of unilateral surgeries having complications. Patients aged 12 years or younger were found to have a 1.12 times greater risk of complications than those older than 12 years of age (RR, 1.12; 95% CI, 0.39-2.71). This increased risk was not statistically significant (Fisher exact test, P = .78), with 18% (5/28) of knees in patients aged 12 years or younger and 16% (24/151) of knees in patients older than 12 years of age having complications.

sec.title: Discussion
sec.p: The MPFL has been recognized as one of the most important passive restraints to lateral patellar translation, and MPFL reconstruction has gained increasing popularity. Because MPFL reconstruction is a relatively new concept, complications related to it have been topics of case reports25,26,38,39 and have sparsely been mentioned within the clinical reports with excellent outcomes at short and medium terms.8,10,11,19,28,40 The ideal femoral attachment point, choice of graft, isometricity of the reconstructed MPFL, tensioning of the graft, and position of the knee during fixation of the graft are controversial issues.2,3,21,34,40

On the basis of computational modeling study, Elias and Cosgarea9 calculated that the compressive forces across the medial patella doubled when a short graft (<3 mm) was combined with proximal positioning of the femoral tunnel. Evaluating 5 patients with technical failure of MPFL reconstruction, Bollier et al4 described 3 possible outcomes of anterior and proximal placement of the femoral tunnel, including medial patellofemoral articular overload, iatrogenic medial subluxation, and recurrent lateral instability due to stretching of the graft. Five patients in our series had increasing patellofemoral arthrosis/pain not amenable to nonoperative treatment. A review of the postoperative images revealed anterior placement of the femoral tunnel in 3 of 5 patients. One patient with soft tissue MPFL reconstruction had anterior and proximal attachments of the graft on the femoral side. Similarly, 7 of 8 patients with recurrent lateral patellar instability had nonanatomic femoral tunnel placement. An anterior or proximal femoral tunnel would lead to increased tightness in flexion and increased medial patellofemoral contact forces.34,38 This may cause pain with flexion, loss of flexion, or stretching of the graft. If the femoral tunnel is placed too distally or posteriorly, the graft would be tight in extension, leading to pain with extension, an extensor lag, or stretching of the graft. The consequences of nonanatomic femoral tunnel placement would also depend on position of the knee during fixation of the graft. For example, if the femoral tunnel is malpositioned anteriorly and the graft is tensioned with the knee in extension, it may lead to tightness and pain during knee flexion. Similarly, if the femoral tunnel is malpositioned anteriorly and the graft is tensioned with the knee in flexion, it may lead to a loose graft and recurrent instability when the knee is extended. Bollier et al4 have asserted that graft tensioning with the knee in extension can produce iatrogenic medial patellar instability, although their assertions were not supported by experimental or clinical studies. Some authors have reported on spontaneous or posttraumatic medial patellar instability,27,32 although medial instability after MPFL reconstruction is highly unlikely in the absence of lateral retinacular release.22 We have not encountered medial instability after MPFL reconstruction in our practice, as we do not perform lateral retinacular release and we routinely fix our grafts with the knee in 45° of flexion when the patella is constrained by the trochlea. All 9 patients who underwent revision MPFL reconstruction had satisfactory relief of their symptoms after appropriate femoral tunnel placement.

The nonanatomic placement of the femoral tunnel is considered to be an avoidable complication. Initially in our series, the femoral tunnel was identified by visual inspection of the medial collateral ligament or palpation of bony landmarks (medial epicondyle, adductor tubercle) during surgery. This was challenging at times because exposure was limited and landmarks were not always identifiable. Sometimes, the size of the knee in an obese patient would preclude adequate visualization or localization of the femoral tunnel. We do not know the number of patients in our cohort who may have had nonanatomic femoral tunnel placement but are asymptomatic to date. Servien et al31 noted that in 35% of their cases, the femoral tunnel was positioned too proximal or too anterior, but the clinical outcomes of their patients did not correlate with the tunnel placement. We currently use intraoperative fluoroscopic identification of femoral tunnel landmarks, as described by Schöttle et al,30 which does help to locate the optimal site for femoral tunnel placement. Once the tunnel position is localized, an isometric check is performed to make any further adjustments. We have not had complications related to femoral tunnel placement using fluoroscopic guidance.

Of 179 knees, 28 MPFL reconstructions were performed in children aged 12 years or younger. The femoral attachment of the MPFL and its relationship to the distal femoral physis in these skeletally immature patients is controversial. We believe the MPFL femoral attachment to be just distal to the physis,13,15 but Shea et al33 reported the MPFL femoral attachment to be proximal to the physis. We do not agree with the study by Shea et al,33 which was based on an indirect localization technique on lateral knee radiographs, because it did not take into account the concave nature of the distal femoral physis. There is a risk for growth disturbances during femoral tunnel placement because of the proximity of the distal femoral physis, and fluoroscopic guidance is recommended. We have not had any growth disturbances in our series. When the attachment site of the femoral tunnel is moved distal to the distal femoral physis, as in our patients, there is a possibility of overtightening the patellofemoral joint in extension. This can be resolved by moving the tunnel anteriorly the amount of distance it was moved distally (Figure 6).

caption.p: (A) Lateral and (B) anteroposterior radiographs of a skeletally immature patient demonstrate the femoral tunnel attachment point, which is distal to the distal femoral physis.

sec.p: The MPFL has been found to be isometric between full extension and 70° of flexion, where isometricity was defined as less than 5 mm of the MPFL length change with knee motion.34 However, Melegari et al17 could not find a significant difference in the knee contact area or contact pressures when comparing a nonisometric femoral attachment point to an isometric attachment point. Similarly, in a cadaveric study, Victor et al42 concluded that the MPFL is nonisometric, with its cranial part being tight at full extension and the caudal part being tight at 30° of knee flexion. Thaunat and Erasmus40 introduced the concept of “favorable anisometry,” where the graft is tensioned in extension so that progressive slackening of the graft could be achieved as the knee flexes. We recommend close attention to graft isometry and fixation of the graft with the knee in 45° of flexion. As the patella engages into the trochlea at 30° of flexion, fixation of the graft in 45° of flexion with no tension would avoid overconstraining the graft. As the native MPFL is lax in flexion, patellar stability should be assessed in extension to avoid too tight fixation of the graft.

Loss of motion has been reported after MPFL reconstruction.6,8,11,38,40 In their series of 44 patients, Christiansen et al6 reported on 4 patients who had loss of flexion of greater than 10° at final follow-up and 1 patient who underwent MUA for flexion less than 90°. Fithian and Gupta11 associated the loss of motion in 4 of their patients to inflammation and scarring in the area of femoral graft attachment. Thaunat and Erasmus38 described percutaneous release of the MPFL graft in 2 of their patients who presented with motion loss, which they believed was caused by overtensioning of the graft. Our rehabilitation protocol after MPFL reconstruction mimics the anterior cruciate ligament rehabilitation protocol.23 The goal is to achieve 0° to 90° of motion at the end of the third postoperative week and 0° to 120° at the end of the sixth week. If the patients cannot meet these goals, we recommend MUA. The aim of this protocol is to prevent arthrofibrosis, which becomes difficult to treat once established. Thus, MUA could be considered a pre-emptive procedure to prevent a major complication of arthrofibrosis. If these 8 patients were excluded, then the complication rate in our series would decrease. Stiffness after MPFL reconstruction could be caused by chondral injuries, femoral tunnel malpositioning, improper graft tensioning, excessive pain, noncompliance with physical therapy, or be idiopathic.38 Imaging analysis of 5 of the 8 patients who underwent MUA revealed malposition of the femoral tunnel (Table 2). One of the 8 patients has undergone revision MPFL reconstruction, and the remaining 7 patients have regained full range of motion and have remained asymptomatic to date.

Patellar fractures after MPFL reconstruction have been reported.6,11,24,26,39 Since these fractures, we have modified our technique of 2 oblique patellar tunnels16 to one 3.5-mm medial tunnel, similar to the tunnel described by Fithian and Gupta11 (Figure 7). In the proximal-distal direction, the tunnel is placed just superior to the middle of the patella. There is concern about single point fixation on the patellar side because it does not replicate the fan-shaped, broad MPFL patellar attachment. Schottle et al29 cautioned that single point fixation on the patella may lead to an increase in the rotational moment of the patella in the flexion-extension plane, although we have not observed such changes in our patients. Variations in the placement of the patellar tunnel can lead to nonisometric graft placement, although studies have shown that the femoral attachment point is more sensitive to graft isometry than patellar tunnels.34

caption.p: Patellar tunnels during medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction. The axial (A) and coronal (B) views of the patella show the previous method of 2 oblique patellar tunnels. (C) Currently, a single 3.5-mm patellar tunnel is used.

sec.p: Two patients in our series developed implant-related pain at the femoral tunnel site and required removal of the interference screw (Figure 8). Nomura et al19 reported a 41% incidence of staple-related pain at the site of femoral fixation. Steiner et al36 reported on 3 patients who desired removal of a prominent or painful screw at the medial epicondyle. In their series of 44 patients, Christiansen et al6 had to remove the interference screw from the medial femoral condyle in 3 patients because of local inflammation between 6 and 12 months postoperatively. They noted that screw placement in this area is susceptible to inflammation because of either excessive mobility of the soft tissues during knee motion or accumulation of small fragments as the biocomposite screw gets resorbed.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance imaging scan with increased signal around the bioabsorbable interference screw, which was subsequently removed.

sec.p: Soft tissue complications included wound dehiscence in 2 patients (anterior knee wound in 1 patient, hamstring harvest wound in 1 patient), hematoma requiring drainage at the site of hamstring harvest in 1 patient, open debridement on the medial aspect of the patella for suture granuloma in 1 patient (Figure 9), and arthroscopic debridement of synovial tissue beneath the medial portal in 1 patient. None of these patients had evidence of infection.

caption.p: Magnetic resonance imaging scan shows a granuloma (arrow) anterior to the reconstructed medial patellofemoral ligament. Open exploration, 1 year after the index surgery, revealed a loose nonabsorbable suture with surrounding exudate.

sec.p: A major limitation of this study is the length of the follow-up. There is a possibility that some patients with complications did not return for follow-up and were treated elsewhere. As patients are followed for a longer duration, the complication rate may increase. The purpose of the study was to caution against early complications and potentially avoid these complications in the future. Recognition of these complications has changed our surgical technique of MPFL reconstruction, including a single patellar tunnel, radiographic confirmation of the femoral tunnel, gracilis autograft to minimize the size of the patellar tunnel, fixation of the graft in 45° of flexion, and checking patellar mobility in extension to avoid overtensioning of the graft (Table 4). Female sex and bilateral MPFL reconstructions were related to higher rates of postoperative complications, which may have been caused by increased severity of underlying patellofemoral dysplasia. We concur with other authors that, although patellar instability is multifactorial, there is seldom any need to address trochlear dysplasia, patellar dysplasia, patella alta, or the lateral retinaculum.36,40 We do not know the incidence of femoral or patellar tunnel malposition after MPFL reconstruction in our series because routine postoperative imaging is not performed. The fate of asymptomatic patients with nonanatomic femoral tunnel placement31 or lateral patellar tracking14 after MPFL reconstruction is not known. Although most patients treated for a complication after MPFL reconstruction had a satisfactory result, long-term follow-up is needed to assess the stability of the patella, progression of arthritis, and functional outcomes. This is even more important when MPFL reconstruction is performed in younger patients.

caption.p: Recommendations for Resolving Challenges and Complications of Medial Patellofemoral Ligament Reconstruction

tr.td: Avoid transverse/long oblique tunnels traversing across the patella (Figures 4, 7)
Gracilis autograft to minimize tunnel diameter
Avoid anterior and/or proximal femoral tunnel malposition (Table 2)
Intraoperative fluoroscopic assessment of femoral tunnel placement (Figure 2)

Check isometry using suture or graft through patellar tunnel and around Beath pin, marking femoral tunnel position; if more than 5 mm of length change with knee flexion and extension, reposition Beath pin
Bend knee to 45° and perform femoral fixation without pulling on graft; then check knee in extension to ensure about one quadrant of lateral patellar translation and no medial tightness
Consider femoral tunnel position relative to distal femoral physis
Femoral tunnel placement to be distal to distal femoral physis and fluoroscopic guidance to avoid iatrogenic physeal injury
Systemic disease (Ehlers-Danlos syndrome or joint hypermobility syndrome)
Genetic screening and allograft consideration in presence of significant joint hyperlaxity

fn.label: a
fn.p: Twenty-eight percent of patients with bilateral medial patellofemoral ligament reconstruction had complications.
The authors declared that they have no conflicts of interest in the authorship and publication of this contribution.
